quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, Luc shares advice on how and when to think about getting a growth advisor, including how to structure the relationship and what to look for in an advisor.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical decision framework for engaging growth advisors and setting up the relationship effectively.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We also spent a ton of time on SEO, how to think about this as a growth channel, who it's well suited for, and how everything is about to change in SEO with Bard and ChatGPT.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Points to a shifting SEO landscape and frames SEO as a strategic growth channel with changing assumptions due to AI search tools.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Plus Luc shares a ton of really interesting advice around the value of self-reflection, building routines, cold plunges, also a couple of amazing stories about working with Zuck and what you learned from him.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Signals actionable personal operating-system practices (reflection and routines) tied to performance and learning from high-performing environments.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Before this, he was recruited personally by Mark Zuckerberg to help grow Facebook Messenger, Instagram and WhatsApp.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete credibility/data point about Luc’s growth experience across multiple flagship products at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Get deep insights into what your users are doing at every stage of the funnel at a fair price that scales as you grow.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a scalable approach to funnel analytics that teams can apply as they grow without outgrowing their tooling.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And by capturing website activity, ad data, and multi-touch attribution right in Mixpanel, you can improve every aspect of the full user funnel.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: unify product + marketing data (including attribution) in one place to optimize the end-to-end funnel.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Powered by first party behavioral data instead of third party cookies, Mixpanel is built to be more powerful and easier to use than Google Analytics.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian positioning that emphasizes first-party behavioral data as a more robust foundation than cookie-based tracking.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It allows you to quickly build a CRM that matches your unique workflows and data structures.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Practical guidance for teams: design your CRM around your actual workflows/data model rather than forcing a generic process.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Within minutes of connecting your email and calendar, you'll have a CRM that's already set up complete with customer profiles and automatic data enrichment.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of rapid CRM setup and automation that reduces manual data entry and speeds time-to-value.

quotes.topic_title: First Facebook exec review: focus on impact
quotes.text: Hey, we saw your presentation, saw your strategy. Now when are we going to start seeing results?
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A concrete example of leadership immediately pushing from plans to measurable outcomes and timelines.

quotes.topic_title: First Facebook exec review: focus on impact
quotes.text: It's because they focus exclusively on that magic word, which is impact.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A simple organizing principle for prioritization and execution: optimize for impact over activity.

quotes.topic_title: First Facebook exec review: focus on impact
quotes.text: it's that difference between, "I don't care how hard you've worked. I don't care what you're working on, what the activities are. What are the outcomes? What is the impact you're having?"
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Actionable performance lens for teams: evaluate work by outcomes/impact rather than effort or busyness.

quotes.topic_title: First Facebook exec review: focus on impact
quotes.text: I actually really love that word impact and focusing on it because it's vague enough that it covers off any work that is impactful towards the mission and it's precise enough to know what does that mean when you say, "Are you having impact? Or what is the impact we're having?"
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A practical mental model for goal-setting language: choose terms that are broad enough to align work to mission yet precise enough to measure.

quotes.topic_title: Impact as a recurring operating principle
quotes.text: I mean I think it's easy for a lot of leaders and companies to get caught up in how hard are people working, what did they do, and recognizing and rewarding activity.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Highlights a common management trap—optimizing for visible effort instead of outcomes—useful for recalibrating incentives and evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Impact as a recurring operating principle
quotes.text: The companies that truly focus on that are the ones that break through and really make a lot of progress towards the mission.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A concise principle linking impact-focus to mission progress, reinforcing impact as a core operating system rather than a slogan.

quotes.topic_title: Impact as a recurring operating principle
quotes.text: but being in that culture and having it really ingrained in everything you do whether it's performance reviews or strategies or these reviews with the executive team, it all gravitates around impact.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: bake impact into the company’s recurring mechanisms (reviews, strategy, exec check-ins) so it becomes default behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Impact as a recurring operating principle
quotes.text: I find it's just such a precise way to think about how people are performing or what you're doing in terms of is your strategy working? Is the direction you're moving in having the intended outcomes that you want?
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Provides a practical evaluation rubric—use impact to test performance and strategy effectiveness via intended outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Impact as a recurring operating principle
quotes.text: Being a growth leader where everything's so measurable, impact is something that can be very clearly measured and you know whether you have it or not.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A measurement-based mental model: in growth work, impact is unambiguous, enabling tighter feedback loops and accountability.

quotes.topic_title: Being recruited by Zuck: hiring lessons
quotes.text: As a leader, hiring is the most important thing as we all know. It's a craft and a skill that I'm always working on refining. I have my own playbook that I'm constantly tweaking, testing out different approaches, trying to find the best talent and assessing them and trying to close them and bringing them on board.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Frames hiring as an iterative craft with a continuously tested “playbook,” emphasizing deliberate practice over ad hoc recruiting.

quotes.topic_title: Being recruited by Zuck: hiring lessons
quotes.text: Mark really involved the entire executive team. It wasn't just me talking to recruiting or talent or HR or just Mark, it was the entire executive team.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Highlights a scalable closing tactic: mobilize the full exec bench rather than relying on HR or a single hiring manager.

quotes.topic_title: Being recruited by Zuck: hiring lessons
quotes.text: But involving somebody's spouse and family I think is a really good idea because it's a very personal decision to change company. It involves more than just that person you're talking to, it involves the whole family.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Offers a practical, often-overlooked recruiting lever: treat the decision as a family decision and involve key stakeholders early.

quotes.topic_title: Being recruited by Zuck: hiring lessons
quotes.text: And then the third thing is just to be absolutely relentless and don't give up and don't let momentum drop. It took seven months for me to go from, "This is amazing, exciting, but there's no way I can make this work" to, "Okay, let's move to Palo Alto."
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A concrete example (seven months) illustrating the “relentless momentum” model for closing hard-to-move candidates.

quotes.topic_title: Being recruited by Zuck: hiring lessons
quotes.text: No doesn't necessarily mean no, and in this case it definitely wasn't the case.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Challenges the default interpretation of rejection, suggesting persistence and continued problem-solving can convert initial “no” into “yes.”

quotes.topic_title: Hiring as a core leadership skill
quotes.text: Well, I think you reach a point in your career where you realize that hiring is the skill you now need to become world-class at because you're not no longer doing the work yourself.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Reframes hiring as the primary leverage point for senior leaders once they’re no longer the main executor.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring as a core leadership skill
quotes.text: My hiring playbook's a similar thing. I think of it in three different chapters, if you will. There's finding talent, assessing talent, and closing talent.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Provides a simple, repeatable framework for structuring the end-to-end hiring process.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring as a core leadership skill
quotes.text: In terms of finding talent, I do believe that the best predictor of future performance is past performance. So I'm looking for what I call signs of excellence.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Gives a concrete evaluation heuristic: anchor on demonstrated past outcomes and explicit “signals” rather than vibes.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring as a core leadership skill
quotes.text: Another great sign of excellence, and this was just through reflecting on stars on the team and thinking what makes them unique, what about them. One of them is when somebody's boss leaves the company and then comes back to poach them, that is such a strong signal because if you think of what just happened, the leader who knows exactly how good this person you're talking to is, they have the most knowledge of the performance of this individual, they left the company. They've come back to poach them, putting their own reputation at risk by coming back depending on the situation. And they would never do that unless this person was really, really good.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Offers a high-signal, real-world indicator of excellence based on revealed preferences and reputational risk.

quotes.topic_title: Hiring as a core leadership skill
quotes.text: So you don't want to over pivot on one signal, you want to look at the full picture.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Adds a practical guardrail: use signals as inputs, but avoid single-metric hiring decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Signs of excellence and early-career signals
quotes.text: Yeah, I mean just thinking off the top, it depends on the type of person you're hiring, but are they a founder? Have they tried to do something? Did they win an award somewhere? Are they a gold medalist at something? Have they done something that others have not that shows grit, that shows drive, that shows the ability to succeed? And I've seen that you can apply that to any candidate you're hiring.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A practical checklist of early-career “signals of excellence” you can use to screen for high performers across roles.

quotes.topic_title: Signs of excellence and early-career signals
quotes.text: Correct, exactly. Yeah, I mean I suppose it's possible, but it would be pretty rare that somebody would come in without some sign that they stand above the crowd.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A strong hiring heuristic: true standout performance usually has prior evidence, even if the candidate is early in their career.

quotes.topic_title: Signs of excellence and early-career signals
quotes.text: And again, I'm talking about you generally want to hire the top 1% of candidates. So when you're looking for the best of the best, you definitely are looking for those signals.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Frames “signals of excellence” as a necessity when your bar is top-1% talent, not a nice-to-have.

quotes.topic_title: When to bring on a growth advisor
quotes.text: But generally speaking, I would say you don't want to focus too much on growth until you have product market fit. So make sure you have a product that users love that's either showing strong signs of retention or has some good loop that you can see that you can start thinking about growth.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A practical gating rule for when to engage growth help, anchored on retention or a visible growth loop as PMF signals.

quotes.topic_title: When to bring on a growth advisor
quotes.text: The problem that I see is if you start growing a product that doesn't have product market fit, you're actually doing more damage than good because you have a product that is now being exposed to the market through growth levers and through optimization that is giving a bad experience with your product.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Explains the core risk of scaling growth pre-PMF: amplification of a bad experience via growth channels.

quotes.topic_title: When to bring on a growth advisor
quotes.text: And you want that product that you know is tight and you know has product market fit to start building the flywheel and start growing. You don't want it to be growing if it doesn't satisfy that need that you're trying to build out for.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A memorable flywheel mental model: only spin up growth once the product reliably satisfies the target need.

quotes.topic_title: When to bring on a growth advisor
quotes.text: So I can see it having more damage than good because when somebody tries something, they're unlikely to try it again. And so that's the dangerous game you can get into.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Highlights the often-underestimated cost of first impressions—premature growth can permanently burn potential users.

quotes.topic_title: When to bring on a growth advisor
quotes.text: Like pick some English-speaking country that's a bit off the grid that you can isolate your marketing to so you can start getting dozens or a couple hundred people per day coming in and giving you feedback.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for “controlled” early growth to gather PMF signal without polluting your main market.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great growth advisor
quotes.text: what makes a great growth advisor is somebody who really understands what to do but also why certain growth levers work.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Defines a clear bar for advisor quality: depth of causal understanding, not just tactics.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great growth advisor
quotes.text: So when you're looking for a growth advisor, you want to have those discussions to see like, "How much depth does this person have? Have they seen a playbook and they're just good at repeating the playbook or are they evolving, are they growing?"
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Gives a practical evaluation method: probe for depth and adaptability vs. rote playbook repetition.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great growth advisor
quotes.text: So if you have an advisor, you can make that one of their roles is vet out any new talent coming in.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Actionable hiring tactic: use trusted growth advisors to screen growth candidates and reduce selection risk.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great growth advisor
quotes.text: We talk about the 10X engineer and we don't really talk about the 10X growth advisor or 10X growth person, but the same dynamic applies.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Memorable reframing that elevates growth talent/advisors to “10x” impact status, not just engineering.

quotes.topic_title: What makes a great growth advisor
quotes.text: As we know, you need a great product and you need a great growth loop. And it's usually just one loop that you need to get right. Most companies have gotten to where they are just off of one really strong channel that they've just dominated, so it's important to get right.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A focused growth model: prioritize finding and perfecting the single dominant loop/channel rather than many.

quotes.topic_title: Advisor impact: needle-in-haystack insights
quotes.text: So once a growth advisor has that, it's takes years to learn it, but it literally can take seconds literally to communicate that.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Captures the core value proposition of experienced advisors: compressed transfer of hard-won experimentation knowledge.

quotes.topic_title: Advisor impact: needle-in-haystack insights
quotes.text: I could see very quickly that there was something they were doing that was a little off and I asked them, "Well, why are you doing it that way?" And they said, "Well, we think it just looks better that way." And I said, "Well, just do it this other way."
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A concrete example of diagnosing a funnel/landing-page issue fast by challenging aesthetic-driven decisions with performance-driven changes.

quotes.topic_title: Advisor impact: needle-in-haystack insights
quotes.text: it's one of those weird disciplines where the right person at the right time can literally say a sentence that changes the trajectory of your company.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that advisory impact can be discontinuous—one insight can outweigh months of execution.

quotes.topic_title: Advisor impact: needle-in-haystack insights
quotes.text: Okay, here's the needle in the haystack" and then it's implemented and you can see hundreds of percentages, sometimes over a thousand percent lift when you get it right.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Highlights the upside of pinpointing the highest-leverage change—massive lifts can come from a single correct diagnosis.

quotes.topic_title: Advisor impact: needle-in-haystack insights
quotes.text: So if you can do it, I would definitely advise founders to bring advisors in for equity if you can.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Actionable compensation guidance: use equity to align incentives and focus advisors on outcomes, not hours.

quotes.topic_title: Structuring advisor relationships: equity and cliffs
quotes.text: I'm a big fan of equity because of the alignment of incentives.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Recommends equity compensation to align advisor and founder incentives toward long-term outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Structuring advisor relationships: equity and cliffs
quotes.text: The ideal engagement would be an advisor comes in, delivers as much value as possible quickly, and then trains your team.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Defines a clear model for advisor engagements focused on rapid impact and capability transfer to the internal team.

quotes.topic_title: Structuring advisor relationships: equity and cliffs
quotes.text: I'm a big fan of vesting earlier rather than later.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Suggests front-loading vesting to incentivize fast knowledge transfer instead of prolonged dependence.

quotes.topic_title: Structuring advisor relationships: equity and cliffs
quotes.text: I'm also a big fan of three month cliffs.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Advocates a short cliff period to quickly validate fit and reduce risk for both founder and advisor.

quotes.topic_title: Structuring advisor relationships: equity and cliffs
quotes.text: You shouldn't need an advisor forever.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Warns founders to structure advisory relationships to build internal competence rather than ongoing dependency.

quotes.topic_title: How to find growth advisors (and vet them)
quotes.text: Depending on your situation, if you're a founder, I would start with your investors. I think VCs have an amazing network of advisors.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A practical sourcing strategy: use investor networks as a high-signal starting point for finding vetted advisors.

quotes.topic_title: How to find growth advisors (and vet them)
quotes.text: The third advice I would give is to find companies that are world-class at what you're trying to grow, what channel or skill you're looking at, and then reach out and see if there's a way to help that way.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A repeatable method for finding (or becoming) growth help by targeting proven “world-class” operators in the exact channel you need.

quotes.topic_title: How to find growth advisors (and vet them)
quotes.text: I didn't take a single shred of equity or money and just tried to have as much impact as possible and to help out this company as much as possible and then make sure that I was able to get connected to other people that I wanted to meet in the Bay Area.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A concrete example of using pro bono impact as a wedge to build credibility and unlock a network, rather than optimizing for immediate compensation.

quotes.topic_title: How to find growth advisors (and vet them)
quotes.text: Even if you bring on an advisor, some advice to founders would be you want to surround your team or at least one person that you've identified who's just a amazing world-class doer, even if they don't know growth, with a set of growth advisors so that they're learning, that's being put through the culture of the company and that knowledge stays inside of the company.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: An internalization model: pair a strong in-house “doer” with advisors so growth capability becomes embedded and retained in the company.

quotes.topic_title: How to find growth advisors (and vet them)
quotes.text: as advice to the people listening, is when you're vetting for a growth advisor or growth talent, don't just wait it on the public halo of somebody.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A cautionary, counterintuitive vetting principle: avoid over-weighting public visibility (followers, talks) versus demonstrated performance.

quotes.topic_title: How to become a growth advisor
quotes.text: Yeah, I think the right mental model as a growth advisor is around the same one as an investor.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A clear framing that helps advisors evaluate opportunities with an investment mindset, not just a service mindset.

quotes.topic_title: How to become a growth advisor
quotes.text: So the most important thing an advisor can do aside from having impact and knowing their craft is picking which companies to work with, especially if you're working for equity.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Emphasizes that selection (portfolio construction) can matter more than execution when compensation is equity-based.

quotes.topic_title: How to become a growth advisor
quotes.text: So you need to put yourself in the shoes of an investor and look at it as an investment.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: A practical decision rule: evaluate advisory engagements the way an investor would assess risk, upside, and liquidity.

quotes.topic_title: How to become a growth advisor
quotes.text: When I'm deciding to work with a company, I'm in there for 10 years and I know that and I say that.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Sets an explicit long-term commitment expectation that changes how advisors should choose companies and structure deals.

quotes.topic_title: How to become a growth advisor
quotes.text: So advice to growth advisors, make sure to ask for a long tail so that you don't end up in a bad spot in the end.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Actionable deal-structuring guidance to avoid equity expiring before a company reaches liquidity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Wherever you work, running experiments is increasingly essential, but there are no commercial tools that integrate with a modern grow team stack.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a common tooling gap that creates friction for modern growth teams and motivates adopting purpose-built experimentation infrastructure.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This leads to waste of time building internal tools or trying to run your own experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable warning about the hidden cost of DIY experimentation or misusing marketing tools for product experiments.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When I was at Airbnb, one of the things that I loved most about working there was our experimentation platform where I was able to slice and dice data by device types, country, user stage.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of the kind of segmentation capabilities that make experimentation more diagnostic and decision-useful.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic click-through metrics and instead use your north star metrics like activation, retention, subscription and payments.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Practical measurement guidance: optimize experiments against business-impact metrics rather than shallow engagement proxies.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's basically free. It continues to work after you stop doing any work on it for a while.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Memorable mental model for why SEO can be uniquely compounding compared to many other growth channels.

quotes.topic_title: SEO segment kickoff: why SEO matters
quotes.text: It's like this amazing growth channel. It's basically free. It continues to work after you stop doing any work on it for a while.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Captures the core mental model for SEO as a compounding, durable acquisition channel with low marginal cost.

quotes.topic_title: SEO segment kickoff: why SEO matters
quotes.text: Many founders think about, "Should we invest in SEO? How do we approach SEO?"
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights the practical decision point founders face—whether and how to prioritize SEO as a growth lever.

quotes.topic_title: SEO segment kickoff: why SEO matters
quotes.text: You helped grow Tripadvisor many years ago and it was mostly SEO-driven.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete example of a major company where SEO was the primary growth engine.

quotes.topic_title: SEO segment kickoff: why SEO matters
quotes.text: In terms of the playbook that we built out.
quotes.speaker: Luc Levesque
quotes.context: Signals that SEO success can be systematized into a repeatable playbook rather than treated as ad-hoc tactics.
